awd_titl_txt: Grain Boundary Diffusion in the Mantle: An Integrated Theoretical and Experimental Study of MgO
awd_abstract_narration:
Transport of atoms along the boundaries between mineral grains is a fundamental but poorly understood process that plays an important role in many important geological phenomena, from the attenuation of seismic energy produced by earthquakes to the many deformation and chemical transport processes associated with mantle convection and plate tectonics. This project supports a combined theoretical and experimental study of grain boundary diffusion in MgO, a major component of Earth's deep mantle.  The results of this study will improve the ability to estimate grain boundary chemical transport rates and related geophysical and geochemical properties of the deep Earth.  

The combined experimental and theoretical research program will specifically target the atomic-level mechanisms involved in grain boundary diffusion, and the influence of pressure, chemical impurities and grain boundary structure on element mobility. Grain boundary diffusion coefficients, and their dependence on temperature, pressure and the presence of calcium and silicon, will be determined using diffusion couple experiments, and first-principles and classical molecular dynamics simulations.  The theoretical simulations will provide critical information on the diffusion mechanism(s), the relation of grain boundary transport to grain boundary structure, and the extrapolation of grain boundary diffusion data to the high pressures relevant to Earth?s deepest mantle.

por.por_cntn:
Migration of atoms along the interfaces between mineral grains – a process termed grain boundary diffusion – plays a critical role in creep deformation, anelasticity and geochemical transport, and is therefore important for understanding mantle convection, seismic attenuation, and a wide range of problems in geochemistry. Because grain boundaries have thicknesses on the order of the size of atoms, diffusion along them is difficult to study directly by experiment. Grain boundary diffusion is also difficult to study using molecular simulations because of the wide range of important length and time scales, which necessitate very large system sizes and simulation durations, as well as novel methodologies to overcome these challenges.

 

Under this award, we developed a rigorous method to obtain grain boundary diffusion coefficients from molecular dynamics simulations, based on an analysis of the potential energy landscape that identifies the grain boundary atoms according to their number of nearest neighbors. The method was applied to grain boundaries in periclase (MgO), the second most abundant mineral in Earth’s deep mantle and possible primary constituent of the deepest mantle, and shown to be in reasonable agreement with the data that are available from experiments. We determined diffusion coefficients in periclase grain boundaries over a broad range of pressures and temperatures relevant to Earth’s mantle, and found that their dependence on both temperature and pressure were significantly larger than had previously been estimated. The stronger than expected increase in grain boundary diffusivity with increasing temperature is linked to a decrease in the order of the atomic structure in the grain boundary. Similarly, the sharp decrease in grain boundary diffusivity with increasing pressure is due to the gradual adoption of more ordered structures. The net result is that diffusion in periclase grain boundaries is predicted to become slower with increasing depth in the mantle. At the core-mantle boundary, grain boundary diffusion is expected to be several orders of magnitude slower than previous estimates based on experimental data at low pressures.  

 

Our work provides a new, more robust conceptual framework for understanding grain boundary diffusion and its dependence on temperature and pressure. It also provides a roadmap for the rigorous determination of grain boundary diffusion coefficients from molecular simulations, which can be applied to a broad range of minerals and other materials.

 

Under this award, we also developed a new molecular-dynamics-based methodology that is the first to address the free energy of binding between cation vacancies and cation impurities with excess charge in crystal interiors. Vacancies that are produced to balance the excess charge of impurities provide the primary mode of diffusional transport in many minerals. Their binding together onto adjacent sites is important because it reduces the diffusivity of other cations that diffuse by hopping to vacant sites, while simultaneously enhancing the diffusivity of the impurity itself. We performed simulations over a wide range of temperature and pressure to determine the binding between cation vacancies and tetravalent impurities in periclase. The entropy and volume of binding were found to be in agreement with experimental constraints, and indicate that bound impurity-vacancy pairs become more prevalent with increasing depth along a mantle adiabat, hence decreasing the efficiency of diffusional transport for most cations.
